comments.author: Sandy
comments.content:
Congratulations!
Another benefit of freezing blue cheese:  If you like blue-cheese dressing (or a sprinkle of it on a standard tossed salad) but don't like huge, overwhelming LUMPS of it, freezing the block and shaving it with a *serrated* knife (like a coarse serrated knife, or Rada's "tomato slicer") will yield a snow-like drift of powder, much more subtle in flavor.  I discovered this in Jr. High School - salads were my dinner job.

comments.author: John
comments.content: None of our family is big on licorice/anise flavors, but we tried this anyhow, and liked it so much that we have made it a second time. The anise flavor is very mild, and the texture and flavor combination is excellent. For those wondering about "lemon juice as needed", half a small lemon is a bit too much. Perhaps a quarter of a small lemon would be better. My son says "I think a little more olive oil would be good." The shaved blue cheese is great, but I'd like to figure out a way to do it without having it tend to curl up into little tubes, which is what I get using a veg. peeler.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Do try the mandoline if you have one, and be sure the cheese is frozen rock solid - you only have a few minutes after it comes out of the freezer before it starts to soften back up and be hard to shave.
